criteria.name: Question Clarification
criteria.1: Question vague, units missing, scope undefined, decision context unclear
criteria.3: Question restated with units, scope bounded, decision context mentioned
criteria.5: Question precise and unambiguous, units specified, scope clearly defined, decision context and required precision explicit

criteria.name: Decomposition Quality
criteria.1: No decomposition or single wild guess, components not estimable, unclear how they combine
criteria.3: Logical decomposition into 2-3 levels, components mostly estimable, formula clear
criteria.5: Elegant decomposition (3-5 levels), all components independently estimable from knowledge/experience, path from components to answer transparent

criteria.name: Assumptions Explicit
criteria.1: Assumptions unstated, black-box numbers with no justification, cannot be challenged
criteria.3: Major assumptions stated, some justification provided, most can be identified and questioned
criteria.5: All assumptions explicitly stated, fully justified with anchors/sources, sensitivity noted, easily challenged and refined

criteria.name: Anchoring
criteria.1: Components based on guesses not anchored in any known quantities, no sources cited
criteria.3: Most components anchored in known data (population, benchmarks, personal experience), some sources mentioned
criteria.5: All components grounded in credible anchors (data, benchmarks, analogies, first principles), sources cited, confidence levels assessed

criteria.name: Bounding
criteria.1: No bounds provided, single point estimate only, no sense of uncertainty range
criteria.3: Upper and lower bounds calculated, range assessed (factor of X), some scenario analysis
criteria.5: Rigorous bounds via optimistic/pessimistic scenarios, range quantified, decision sensitivity assessed (does decision change across range?), constraints checked

criteria.name: Calculation Correctness
criteria.1: Math errors, units don't match, formula incorrect, compounding mistakes
criteria.3: Math generally correct, units mostly consistent, formula works, minor errors possible
criteria.5: Math accurate, dimensional analysis verified (units cancel correctly), formula logic sound, calculation transparent and reproducible

criteria.name: Sanity Checking
criteria.1: No validation, answer not compared to reality, obvious errors not caught
criteria.3: Some sanity checks (order of magnitude comparison, gut check), major errors would be caught
criteria.5: Comprehensive validation (dimensional analysis, reality comparison, extreme case testing, derived metrics consistency, gut check), implausible results flagged and investigated

criteria.name: Triangulation
criteria.1: Single approach only, no alternate path, cannot validate estimate
criteria.3: Attempted alternate decomposition, comparison made, discrepancies noted
criteria.5: Multiple independent paths (top-down vs bottom-up, supply vs demand), estimates within factor of 3, reconciliation of differences, confidence increased by agreement

criteria.name: Precision Appropriate
criteria.1: False precision (8.372M when uncertainty is ±10×), or uselessly vague ("a lot"), wrong significant figures
criteria.3: Rounded to 1-2 significant figures, order of magnitude clear, some uncertainty acknowledged
criteria.5: Precision matches uncertainty (1 sig fig for ±3×, 2 sig figs for ±30%), expressed as range when appropriate, confidence intervals calibrated, avoids false precision trap

criteria.name: Decision Actionability
criteria.1: Estimate disconnected from decision, no recommendation, unclear how to use result
criteria.3: Connection to decision mentioned, some implication for action, directionally useful
criteria.5: Clear decision implication (go/no-go, prioritize/deprioritize), threshold analysis (if >X then Y), sensitivity to key assumptions identified, actionable recommendation based on estimate and uncertainty

key_requirements: Top-down decomposition (population → filters → addressable → price), components estimable from census/industry data
Anchors: Population figures, market penetration rates, pricing from comparables, industry reports
Bounds: Optimistic (high penetration, premium price) vs Pessimistic (low penetration, discount price)
Triangulation: Cross-check against public company revenues in space, VC market estimates, bottom-up from customer count
Sanity check: Compare to GDP (market can't exceed consumer spending), check per-capita figures
common_pitfalls: Confusing TAM (total addressable) with SAM (serviceable) or SOM (obtainable)
Overestimating willingness to pay (assume most won't pay)
Not accounting for competition (you won't get 100% share)

key_requirements: Decomposition: Users → Actions per user → Resources per action → Overhead/utilization
Anchors: Similar systems (Instagram scale), known limits (AWS instance capacity), load testing data, utilization factors (70-80% not 100%)
Bounds: Peak load (Black Friday, viral event) vs Average, Growth trajectory (2× vs 10× per year)
Triangulation: Top-down from users vs Bottom-up from server capacity, cost validation (does $/user make sense?)
Sanity check: Cost per user < LTV, compare to public cloud bills of similar companies
common_pitfalls: Linear scaling assumptions (ignoring caching, batching gains)

key_requirements: Decomposition: Revenue (customers × conversion × ARPU), Costs (COGS + CAC + R&D + G&A)
Anchors: Cohort data (historical conversion), industry benchmarks (CAC/LTV ratios, SaaS metrics), comparable company metrics
Bounds: Bull case (high growth, efficient scaling) vs Bear case (slow growth, rising costs)
Triangulation: Build cohort model vs top-down market share model, cross-check margins with industry
Sanity check: Growth follows S-curve not exponential forever, margins approach industry norms at scale, rule of 40
common_pitfalls: Not accounting for churn (especially in SaaS)

key_requirements: Decomposition: Work to be done (features, tickets, customers) → Productivity per person → Overhead (meetings, vacation, ramp)
Anchors: Team velocity (story points/sprint), industry ratios (support agents per 1000 customers), hiring timelines
Bounds: Experienced team (high productivity, low ramp) vs New team (learning curve, attrition)
Triangulation: Bottom-up from roadmap vs Top-down from revenue per employee benchmark
Sanity check: Headcount vs revenue growth (should correlate), compare to peer companies at similar scale
common_pitfalls: Not accounting for ramp time (new hires take 3-6 months to full productivity)
Ignoring overhead (meetings, hiring, training consume 20-30% of time)
Underestimating hiring pipeline (offer to start date 1-3 months)

key_requirements: Decomposition: Total impact = Units affected × Impact per unit × Duration, account for baseline and counterfactual
Anchors: Emission factors (kg CO2/kWh), conversion rates (program → behavior change), precedent studies with measured effects
Bounds: Conservative (low adoption, small effect) vs Optimistic (high adoption, large effect)
Triangulation: Top-down (total population × penetration) vs Bottom-up (measured cases × scale factor)
Sanity check: Impact should scale linearly or sub-linearly (diminishing returns), compare to similar interventions
common_pitfalls: Not accounting for counterfactual (what would have happened anyway)
Linear extrapolation when effects have diminishing returns

Simple Question (1-2 levels).description: Single decomposition (A × B), components directly estimable, low uncertainty
key_requirements: Clear decomposition (2-3 components), formula transparent
Components anchored in known quantities or personal experience
Basic bounds (±2-3×), sanity check against reality
Single approach sufficient if well-validated

Moderate Question (3-4 levels).description: Multi-level decomposition, some uncertainty in components, decision depends on order of magnitude
key_requirements: Logical 3-4 level decomposition, all components independently estimable
Assumptions explicit, anchored in data or benchmarks
Bounds calculated (optimistic/pessimistic scenarios), range assessed
Triangulation via alternate path, estimates within factor of 3
Comprehensive sanity checks (units, reality comparison, derived metrics)

Complex Question (5+ levels).description: Deep decomposition tree, high uncertainty, decision sensitive to assumptions, requires triangulation
key_requirements: Sophisticated decomposition (5+ levels or multiple parallel paths), components validated independently
All assumptions stated and justified, sensitivity analysis (which matter most?)
Rigorous bounding (scenario analysis, constraint checking), decision sensitivity assessed
Multiple triangulation paths (top-down/bottom-up, supply/demand), cross-validation with public data
Extensive sanity checking (dimensional analysis, extreme cases, internal consistency)
Uncertainty quantified (confidence intervals), precision matched to uncertainty
examples: Multi-year financial model (revenue streams × growth × costs × scenarios)
Climate impact assessment (emissions × multiple sources × counterfactual × time horizon)
Large infrastructure sizing (users × behavior × compute × storage × network × redundancy)

common_failure_modes.symptom: Mixing per-day with per-year, confusing millions and billions, currency not specified, units don't cancel in formula
common_failure_modes.detection: Dimensional analysis fails (units don't match), or derived metrics nonsensical (revenue per employee = $5)
common_failure_modes.fix: Always write units next to every number, verify dimensional analysis (units cancel to expected final unit), convert all to common time basis before combining

common_failure_modes.symptom: Numbers appear without justification, reader cannot challenge or refine estimate, black-box calculation
common_failure_modes.detection: Ask 'Why this number?' and no answer is provided in documentation
common_failure_modes.fix: For each component, explicitly state assumption and anchor (e.g., 'Assuming 250 workdays/year', 'Based on industry benchmark of 3% conversion')

common_failure_modes.symptom: 8.372M when uncertainty is ±5×, or $47,293 when components are rough guesses
common_failure_modes.detection: More than 2 significant figures, or precision implies certainty mismatched to actual uncertainty
common_failure_modes.fix: Round to 1-2 significant figures matching uncertainty (±3× → 1 sig fig, ±30% → 2 sig figs), express as range when uncertainty high

common_failure_modes.symptom: Single point estimate, no validation, implausible result not caught (market size exceeds GDP, growth >100%/year sustained)
common_failure_modes.detection: Estimate seems wrong intuitively but no mechanism to validate, or obviously violates constraints
common_failure_modes.fix: Always calculate bounds (optimistic/pessimistic), compare to known comparables, check extreme cases, verify doesn't violate physics/economics

common_failure_modes.symptom: Components still too complex ('estimate market size' → 'estimate demand' is not progress), or circular (define A in terms of B, B in terms of A)
common_failure_modes.detection: Ask 'Can I estimate this component from knowledge/data?' If no, decomposition incomplete
common_failure_modes.fix: Decompose until each component answerable from: known data, personal experience, analogous comparison, or first principles

common_failure_modes.symptom: Estimate heavily influenced by first number heard, even if irrelevant ('Is it $10M?' causes you to anchor near $10M)
common_failure_modes.detection: Estimate changes significantly based on arbitrary starting point provided
common_failure_modes.fix: Generate independent estimate before seeing any suggested numbers, then compare and justify any convergence

common_failure_modes.symptom: Same quantity included twice in formula (counting businesses AND employees when businesses already includes employee count)
common_failure_modes.detection: Draw decomposition tree visually - if same box appears twice in different branches, likely double-counted
common_failure_modes.fix: Clearly define what each component includes and excludes, ensure mutually exclusive and collectively exhaustive (MECE)

common_failure_modes.symptom: Single path only, cannot validate estimate, reader must trust decomposition is correct
common_failure_modes.detection: Only one approach provided, no alternate path or comparison to known data
common_failure_modes.fix: Re-estimate via different decomposition (top-down vs bottom-up, supply vs demand), check if within factor of 3, cross-validate with public data when available

common_failure_modes.symptom: Assuming 100% capacity (servers always at max, people work 40hr with zero meetings/vacation, factories run 24/7 with no downtime)
common_failure_modes.detection: Capacity estimates seem too high compared to real systems
common_failure_modes.fix: Apply realistic utilization factors (servers 70-80%, people 60-70% after meetings/overhead, factories 80-90% after maintenance)

common_failure_modes.symptom: Assuming linear when exponential (tech adoption), or exponential when logistic (growth eventually saturates)
common_failure_modes.detection: Projections violate constraints (market share >100%, growth continues at 100%/year for decades)
common_failure_modes.fix: Check if relationship is truly linear, apply appropriate growth curve (exponential for early adoption, S-curve for saturation, linear for steady-state)
